message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of vesiculopustular lesions on the dorsum of both wrists and hands, along with recent sexual activity, suggests disseminated gonococcal infection. Lyme arthritis and reactive arthritis usually follow a tick bite or a recent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection, respectively. Acute rheumatic fever usually presents with migratory joint pain and carditis, rather than localized wrist pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The recent camping trip and sexually active status suggest the most likely cause is disseminated gonococcal infection. The presence of vesiculopustular lesions on the hands and wrist reinforces this diagnosis. Lyme arthritis is usually associated with a single swollen, painful joint and a history of tick exposure. Acute rheumatic fever typically involves multiple joints and occurs 2-4 weeks after a streptococcal infection. Reactive arthritis typically occurs 2-4 weeks after a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection and typically affects the lower extremities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the most likely diagnosis is disseminated gonococcal infection. The recent camping trip is unlikely to cause these symptoms. There is no mention of sore throat or other symptoms that suggest acute rheumatic fever. The presence of vesiculopustular lesions on both wrists and hands is not consistent with Lyme arthritis or reactive arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s recent camping trip and sexual activity suggest that the most likely diagnosis is Disseminated gonococcal infection. The presence of violaceous vesiculopustular lesions on the dorsum of both wrists and hands and swelling and erythema of the left wrist are consistent with this diagnosis. Lyme arthritis usually presents with joint swelling and erythema, but not vesiculopustular lesions. Acute rheumatic fever presents with migratory arthritis, carditis, and rash. Reactive arthritis presents with asymmetric arthritis, uveitis, and oral ulcers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of recent camping trip and sexual activity, which makes Disseminated gonococcal infection the most likely diagnosis. The presence of violaceous vesiculopustular lesions on the dorsum of both wrists and hands also supports this diagnosis. Lyme arthritis usually presents with joint pain and inflammation but without vesiculopustular lesions. Acute rheumatic fever and reactive arthritis are also possible causes of joint pain, but they are not associated with the specific dermatological findings described in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s recent trip and sexual activity suggest a possible sexually transmitted infection. The vesiculopustular lesions and joint pain suggest disseminated gonococcal infection. Lyme arthritis usually presents with a rash, fever, and joint pain, but not with the lesions described in this case. Acute rheumatic fever and reactive arthritis are not associated with vesiculopustular lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s recent camping trip to Minnesota suggests the possibility of Lyme disease, but the presence of painless vesiculopustular lesions on both hands and wrists, along with chills and malaise, suggests the most likely diagnosis is disseminated gonococcal infection. The presence of a diaphragm as a method of contraception also increases the risk of gonococcal infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of recent camping trip and sexual activity in addition to the symptoms suggest disseminated gonococcal infection. Lyme arthritis and acute rheumatic fever usually do not present with vesiculopustular lesions, and reactive arthritis typically occurs after a known infection in another part of the body. Swelling and erythema of the left wrist with severe tenderness to palpation and passive movement are consistent with joint involvement in disseminated gonococcal infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of chills, malaise, and the recent camping trip suggest a possible bacterial infection. The violaceous vesiculopustular lesions on the hands support the diagnosis of gonococcal infection, which can also cause joint pain and swelling. Lyme arthritis usually presents with joint pain and erythema migrans, while acute rheumatic fever and reactive arthritis are associated with recent infections and do not typically involve the hand lesions seen here.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of painful wrist, chills, and recent knee pain suggest a possible infection, and the presence of vesiculopustular lesions on the hands and wrists indicates a possible disseminated gonococcal infection. Lyme arthritis typically presents with joint pain and erythema migrans, acute rheumatic fever is associated with group A streptococcal infection and presents with migratory joint pain and carditis, and reactive arthritis is associated with a recent infection elsewhere and presents with joint pain and swelling.
